questions.question_text_1: A researcher wants to investigate the relationship between studying hours and exam scores. He collects the data on studying hours and exam scores from a sample of 100 students and perform a correlation analysis. Which branch of statistics does this analysis belong to?
question_texts: A researcher wants to investigate the relationship between studying hours and exam scores. He collects the data on studying hours and exam scores from a sample of 100 students and perform a correlation analysis. Which branch of statistics does this analysis belong to?

options.option_text: It is a time series Data.
It is a cross sectional Data.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is/are correct?
question_texts: Which of the following is/are correct?

options.option_text: Mean and Mode can only be defined for a numerical data.
Mode can be defined for a categorical data.
There can be more than one mode for a data.
Median can be measured for a categorical variable only if the variable isnominal.
The sum of relative frequencies of all the observations in a given data set isalways equal to 1.

questions.question_text_1: The mean and sample variance of the data set consisting of 10 observations is 22 and 81 respectively. Later it is noted that one observation 20 is wrongly noted as 15. what is the sample standard deviation of the original data set?(Enter the answer correct to two decimal accuracy)
question_texts: The mean and sample variance of the data set consisting of 10 observations is 22 and 81 respectively. Later it is noted that one observation 20 is wrongly noted as 15. what is the sample standard deviation of the original data set?(Enter the answer correct to two decimal accuracy)

questions.question_text_1: A clothe retailer wants to analyze the prices of different brands of t-shirts in his store. He randomly collected 10 t-shirts and prices (in rupees) of the t-shirts are 150, 550, 700, 240, 300, 750, 200, 180, 320, 420 respectively.  Based on the information, answer the given subquestions.
